description: From Medieval Latin castellātus (“fortified, castellate”), from castellum (“little fortification, castle”) + -ātus (“-ate”, forming adjectives).

adjectives.description: castellate (comparative more castellate, superlative most castellate)

entries.meaning: (rare) castle-like: built or shaped like a castle.
examples: ...The living porphyry, in towers aroundGrotesquely castellate...

entries.meaning: (rare) Castled: having or furnished with castles.
(rare) Housed or kept in a castle.
(historical, rare, obsolete) The district of a castle.
examples: In the Castellate of Roger of Poictou...

verbs.description: castellate (third-person singular simple present castellates, present participle castellating, simple past and past participle castellated)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make into a castle: to build in the form of a castle or to add battlements to an existing building.
examples: The citizen who castellates a Villa at Richmond...

entries.meaning: (intransitive, rare) To take the form of a castle.
